By Saqib Iqbal Ahmed
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Prospects that the presidential election will inject a hefty dose of volatility into U.S. stock markets are fading fast as Republican Donald Trump's victory odds lengthen.A reading of positioning data on options tied to the benchmark S&P 500 index shows little pickup in demand for contracts that would offer investors downside insurance in the event that stock prices take a major hit right after the Nov. 8 election.Moreover
column2: based on options term structures - calculated from prices of options with different expirations - it is hardly evident at all that investors are positioning for an uncertain outcome

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-electoral-idUSKCN12M0JR	Clinton far ahead in Electoral College race: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Maurice Tamman
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton maintained her commanding lead in the race to win the Electoral College and claim the U.S. presidency
column2: according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project results released on Saturday.In the last week
column3: there has been little movement. Clinton leads Donald Trump in most of the states that Trump would need should he have a chance to win the minimum 270 votes needed to win. According to the project
column4: she has a better than 95 percent chance of winning
column5: if the election was held this week. The mostly likely outcome would be 326 votes for Clinton to 212 for Trump.Trump came off his best debate performance of the campaign Wednesday evening but the polling consensus still showed Clinton winning the third and final face-off on prime-time TV. Trump disputes those findings.And some national polls had the race tightening a wee bit this week though others had Clinton maintaining her solid lead. But the project illustrates that the broader picture remains bleak for Trump with 17 days to go until the Nov. 8 election.

column1: Trump did gain ground in South Carolina where his slim lead last week expanded to seven points
column2: moving it into his column from a toss-up. Unfortunately for him
column3: he lost ground in Arizona
column4: which is now too close to call.Additionally
column5: he is facing a challenge for Utah's six Electoral College votes from former CIA operative and Utah native Evan McMullin. The independent candidate is siphoning votes away from Trump in a state that is Republican as any in the nation. In some polls
column6: McMullin is even leading. (The States of the Nation is not polling on McMullin.)Utah
column7: like almost all of the states

column1: Clinton has also maintained a lead in Florida and Pennsylvania
column2: which have a combined 49 Electoral College votes. Ohio remains too close to call.According to the project
column3: lower voter turnout generally benefits Trump but his best hope for success is if Republican turnout surges and Democratic turnout is low.

column1: To examine these results and other scenarios
column2: go to the States of the Nation project here . (Editing by Bernard Orr)"

column1: 7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-gettysburg-idUSKCN12M0CU	Trump to lay out what he would do in first 100 days if elected president	"

Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump will lay out on Saturday what he would do in the first 100 days of his administration should he win the Nov. 8 election.Trump's outline - which he will deliver in a speech in the historic town of Gettysburg
column2: Pennsylvania - will cover his plans for boosting Americans' economic and physical security and contrast them with those of Democrat Hillary Clinton
column3: campaign aides told reporters on Friday.Clinton published a book of her own policy ideas earlier this year.Trump is trailing Clinton in most polls - although he has narrowed the gap according to a Reuters/Ipsos poll released on Friday - and has less than three weeks to catch up. Much of the campaign in recent weeks has focused on allegations that he made improper advances to women over decades

column4: which has suffered a schism between his supporters and the party's establishment.
